title: Post With Code
text: This is a post with executable code.

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

objectID: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html
href: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html
title: Spain contribution to European GDP growth
text: A journalist recently asked my colleagues if an statement from a politician was true. The statement was that Spain represented half of the European growth. In this (first) post, we would learn how to calculate that metric using Eurostat data and a bit of R.

objectID: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html#annual-data
href: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html#annual-data
title: Spain contribution to European GDP growth
text:
Annual data
First, I will show the more direct way to do it for annual data. If we want to calculate it for 2024, we need to get the data for Spain and the EU (or Euro area) for 2023 in current prices and for 2024 in previous year prices (prices of 2023). By difference, we can calculate the volume change in both areas.
First we load the libraries.

library(eurostat)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)

And we collect the data we need. First, the year 2023 in current prices:

dat_23 <- get_eurostat("nama_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CP_MEUR"),
                                   time_period = 2023),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_23)




geo
time
values




EU27_2020
2023
17197822


EA20
2023
14598181


ES
2023
1498324





And after, the year 2024 in previous year prices:

dat_24 <- get_eurostat("nama_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("PYP_MEUR"),
                                   time_period = 2024),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_24)




geo
time
values




EU27_2020
2024
17372727


EA20
2024
14722950


ES
2024
1546966





We bind them together and calculate the change between 2024 and 2023:

dat <- bind_rows(dat_23, dat_24) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = time,
              values_from = values) |> 
  mutate(change = `2024` - `2023`,
         change_p = round(change / `2023` * 100, 2))  

knitr::kable(dat)




geo
2023
2024
change
change_p




EU27_2020
17197822
17372727
174905.4
1.02


EA20
14598181
14722950
124768.8
0.85


ES
1498324
1546966
48642.0
3.25





Spain grew by 3.25 in 2024 and the EU by 1.02. But as we are looking for the contribution, we need to divide the change in Spain with the change in the EU.

cont_es_24_eu <- round(dat |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(change) |> pull() / 
                       dat |> filter(geo == "EU27_2020") |> select(change) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)

cont_es_24_ea <- round(dat |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(change) |> pull() / 
                       dat |> filter(geo == "EA20") |> select(change) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)

For the EU aggregate the contribution by Spain was 27.81 and for the Euro area 38.99.

objectID: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html#quarterly-data
href: posts/Spain contribution to European GDP growth/index.html#quarterly-data
title: Spain contribution to European GDP growth
text:
Quarterly data
For quarterly data, to compare the fourth quarter of 2024 with the fourth quarter of 2023, we cannot compare current prices in 2023Q4, which are measured at the prices of 2023Q4, with the previous year prices of 2024Q4, which are measured at the prices of 2023. The easiest way is to use the 2023Q4 in current prices as weights for the start of the period and calculate the change between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4 in chain linked series, which provide the volume evolution.
First the current prices for 2023Q4:

dat_23_q4 <- get_eurostat("namq_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CP_MEUR"),
                                   s_adj = "SCA",
                                   time_period = "2024-Q4"),
                    time_format = "raw") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_23_q4)




geo
time
values




EU27_2020
2024-Q4
4554634


EA20
2024-Q4
3842814


ES
2024-Q4
407457





And then the chain linked data for 2024Q4 and 2023Q4.

dat_24_q4 <- get_eurostat("namq_10_gdp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES", "EA20", "EU27_2020"),
                                   na_item = "B1GQ",
                                   unit = c("CLV20_MEUR"),
                                   s_adj = "SCA",
                                   time_period = c("2023-Q4","2024-Q4")),
                    time_format = "raw") |> 
  select(geo, time, values)

knitr::kable(dat_24_q4)




geo
time
values




EU27_2020
2023-Q4
3758731


EU27_2020
2024-Q4
3810585


EA20
2023-Q4
3213335


EA20
2024-Q4
3250471


ES
2023-Q4
331427


ES
2024-Q4
342982





We compute the change between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4.

q_change <- dat_24_q4 |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = time,
              values_from = values) |> 
  mutate(change_p = round(`2024-Q4` / `2023-Q4` * 100-100, 3))

knitr::kable(dat_24_q4)




geo
time
values




EU27_2020
2023-Q4
3758731


EU27_2020
2024-Q4
3810585


EA20
2023-Q4
3213335


EA20
2024-Q4
3250471


ES
2023-Q4
331427


ES
2024-Q4
342982





Spain grew by 3.486 between 2024Q4 and 2023Q4 and the EU by 1.38.
We combine both datasets to calculate the contribution:

dat_23_q4$time <- NULL
q_change <- q_change |> 
  select(geo,change_p) 
  
contrib_q <- full_join(dat_23_q4, q_change) |> 
  mutate(contrib = values * change_p)

knitr::kable(contrib_q)




geo
values
change_p
contrib




EU27_2020
4554634
1.380
6285395


EA20
3842814
1.156
4442293


ES
407457
3.486
1420395






cont_es_24q4_eu <- round(contrib_q |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(contrib) |> pull() / 
                       contrib_q |> filter(geo == "EU27_2020") |> select(contrib) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)

cont_es_24q4_ea <- round(contrib_q |> filter(geo == "ES") |> select(contrib) |> pull() / 
                       contrib_q |> filter(geo == "EA20") |> select(contrib) |> pull()
                       * 100, 2)

For the EU the contribution was 22.6 and for the Euro area 31.97.
It seems that the statement was not correct, although my guess is that probably the politician was adding Portugal and referring to the Euro area. I leave it as an exercise to calculate the contribution of Spain and Portugal.

title: Bookmarks 20250316
text:
I collect for reference some of the readings I found interesting/useful this week.

data.table vs dplyr: A Side-by-Side Comparison https://albert-rapp.de/posts/34_datatable_vs_dplyr/34_datatable_vs_dplyr.html

As I need to use (read/write) data.table quite often but I am still more familiar with dplyr, all references are useful.

¿Por qué el Gasto Público forma parte del PIB? https://nadaesgratis.es/antonia-diaz/por-que-el-gasto-publico-forma-parte-del-pib

No estoy muy de acuerdo en que sea correcto añadir los automóviles de los particulares al stock de capital y calcular una depreciación para ellos.

Build a Personal Website with Quarto & Github Pages | Lesson 4, Websites and Dashboards with R https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OlvO-EG-P60

Nice youtube tutorial that helped me a lot to build this site on github pages. There are also other useful tutorials for quarto dashboards and basic understanding of using git.

A Country Is Not a Company by Paul Krugman https://hbr.org/1996/01/a-country-is-not-a-company

A classic article that I probably read a long time ago but that I find quite insighful.

title: Expenditure on defence
text:
https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/products-manuals-and-guidelines/w/ks-gq-23-002

library(eurostat)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)


dat <- get_eurostat("gov_10a_exp", 
                    filters = list(geo = c("ES","EU27_2020"),
                                   sector = "S13",
                                   unit = c("MIO_EUR", "PC_GDP"),
                                   cofog99 = c("GF02", "GF0201", "GF0202", "GF0203", "GF0204", "GF0205")),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  na.omit()

labels_cofog <- get_eurostat_dic("cofog99") |> 
  select(cofog99 = code_name, cofog99_label = full_name)

labels_na_item <- get_eurostat_dic("na_item") |> 
  select(na_item = code_name, na_item_label = full_name)

dat <- left_join(dat, labels_cofog) %>%
  left_join(.,labels_na_item)


dat |> filter(cofog99 == "GF02" & na_item == "TE" & unit == "PC_GDP") |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = time, y = values, colour = geo)) +
  geom_line()

title: Negative emissions footprints
text:
https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/products-manuals-and-guidelines/w/ks-gq-23-002

library(eurostat)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)


dat <- get_eurostat("env_ac_ghgfp", 
                    filters = list(time_period = 2020),
                    time_format = "num") |> 
  na.omit()

labels_cofog <- get_eurostat_dic("cofog99") |> 
  select(cofog99 = code_name, cofog99_label = full_name)

labels_na_item <- get_eurostat_dic("na_item") |> 
  select(na_item = code_name, na_item_label = full_name)

dat <- left_join(dat, labels_cofog) %>%
  left_join(.,labels_na_item)


dat |> filter(cofog99 == "GF02" & na_item == "TE" & unit == "PC_GDP") |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = time, y = values, colour = geo)) +
  geom_line()
